org.funcito

Class FuncitoRxJava

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.funcito.FuncitoRxJava

  • public class FuncitoRxJava
extends Object
    This class is the static entry point of the Funcito API for the Netflix RxJava framework.

    • Method Detail

      • callsTo

        public static <T> T callsTo(Class<T> clazz)
        Generates a proxy object for use with other FuncitoRxJava static methods. This proxy should not be used for any other purposes. It is a convenience pass-thru to FuncitoDelegate.callsTo(Class). Example usages are: 

         
     // inlined:
     Func1<MyClass,RetType1> func = func1For( callsTo(MyClass.class).methodWithRetType1() );

     // or extracted for repeat usage
     final MyClass CALLS_TO = callsTo(MyClass.class);
     Func1<MyClass,RetType1> func2 = func1For( CALLS_TO.method1WithRetType1() );
     Func1<MyClass,RetType2> func3 = func1For( CALLS_TO.method2WithRetType2() );

        Stubs are cached, so this method can be called multiple times for the same class without penalty. But a single proxy can also be reused for creating multiple RxJava Func1 objects.

        Parameters:
        clazz - is the class to be proxied
        Returns:
        a proxy which can be used by other FuncitoRxJava static methods

      • func1For

        public static <T,V> Func1<T,V> func1For(V proxiedMethodCall)
        Generates a RxJava Func1 object that wraps a method call or method chain. Resulting Func1 is as thread-safe as the method itself. Example usage is:

        Func1<MyClass,RetType1> func = func1For( callsTo(MyClass.class).methodWithRetType1() );

        You can wrap methods with parameters, so long as you statically provide values for each parameter. Provided parameter values are statically bound to the Func1 and may not be changed:

        Func1<MyClass,RetType1> func = func1For( callsTo(MyClass.class).methodWithArgs("abc", 123L) );
        // all invocations of func will use "abc" and 123L as the arguments to methodWithArgs

        It is also possible to wrap method call chains, with some restrictions:

        MyClass callsTo = callsTo(MyClass.class);
        Func1<MyClass,RetType2> func = func1For( callsTo.methodWithRetType1().methodWithRetType2() );

        Restrictions for chaining are that intermediate return types (all except for the final return type in the chain) must be proxyable by the current Proxy provider, just like the initial target type. In the above example this means MyClass and RetType1 must be proxyable, but RetType2 need not be proxyable. Intermediate return types also cannot be a Java Generic type because of type erasure.

        Parameters:
        proxiedMethodCall - is the return value from a method call to a FuncitoRxJava proxy object
        Returns:
        a RxJava Func1 object that wraps the method call or chain.

      • func1For

        Returns:

        See Also:

      • action1For

        public static <T> Action1<T> action1For(Object proxiedMethodCall)
        Generates a RxJava Action1 object that wraps a method call or method chain. Resulting Action1 is as thread-safe as the method/chain itself. This Action1 generator can only be used for method calls/chains with a non-void return type, even though the return type is ignored. For a Action1 generator that works with void returning methods/chains, see voidAction1(). Example usage is:

        Action1<MyClass> cmd = callbackFor( callsTo(MyClass.class).methodWithNonVoidReturnType() );

        You can wrap methods with parameters, so long as you statically provide values for each parameter. Provided parameter values are statically bound to the Action1 and may not be changed:

        Action1<MyClass> action = action1For( callsTo(MyClass.class).methodWithArgs("abc", 123L) );
        // all invocations of action will use "abc" and 123L as the arguments to methodWithArgs

        It is also possible to wrap method call chains, with some restrictions:

        MyClass callMyClass = callsTo(MyClass.class);
        Action1<MyClass> action = action1For( callsMyClass.methodWithRetType1().methodWithRetType2() );

        Restrictions for chaining are that intermediate return types (all except for the final return type in the chain) must be proxyable by the current Proxy provider, just like the initial target type. In the above example this means MyClass and RetType1 must be proxyable, but RetType2 need not be proxyable. Intermediate return types also cannot be a Java Generic type because of type erasure.

        Type Parameters:
        T - is the input type of the Action1
        Parameters:
        proxiedMethodCall - is the return value from an inlined method call to a FuncitoFJ proxy object
        Returns:
        a RxJava Action1 object that wraps a method call or chain.
        See Also:
        voidAction1()

      • action1For

        public static <T> Action1<T> action1For(Object proxiedMethodCall,

        See Also:
        action1For(Object), Modes, TypedMode

      • prepareVoid

        public static <T> T prepareVoid(T t)
        Prepares a method-call or method-chain call that terminates with a void return type, for generation of an RxJava Action1 object. Use of this method must be followed with execution of one of the void-Action1 methods: voidAction1(), voidAction1(TypedMode), voidAction1(Mode). Resulting Action1 is as thread-safe as the method/chain itself. Example usage is:

        prepareVoid(callsTo(MyClass.class)).methodWithVoidReturnType();

        You can wrap methods with parameters, so long as you statically provide values for each parameter. Provided parameter values are statically bound to the Action1 and may not be changed:

        prepareVoid(callsTo(MyClass.class)).voidMethodWithArgs("abc", 123L);
        // all invocations of Action1 will use "abc" and 123L as the arguments to voidMethodWithArgs

        It is also possible to wrap method call chains, with some restrictions:

        MyClass callMyClass = callsTo(MyClass.class);
        prepareVoid(callsMyClass).methodWithRetType1().voidMethod();

        Restrictions for chaining are that intermediate return types (final return type does not matter because it is void) must be proxyable by the current Proxy provider, just like the initial target type. In the above example this means MyClass and RetType1 must be proxyable. Intermediate return types also cannot be a Java Generic type because of type erasure.

        Type Parameters:
        T - is the input type of the Action1 being prepared
        Returns:
        the same Funcito proxy object that is passed in. Provided for fluent API so that desired method chain call may be directly appended.
        See Also:
        voidAction1()

      • voidAction1

        public static <T> Action1<T> voidAction1()
        Generates a RxJava Action1 object that wraps a method call or method chain. Resulting Action1 is as thread-safe as the method/chain itself. This Action1 generator is only appropriate for method calls/chains with a void return type, and it requires previous usage of prepareVoid(Object). Example usage is:

        prepareVoid(callsTo(MyClass.class)).methodWithVoidReturnType();
        Action1<MyClass> action = voidAction1();

        Type Parameters:
        T - is the input type of the Action1
        Returns:
        an RxJava Action1 object that wraps a previously prepared method call or chain.
        See Also:
        prepareVoid(Object)

      • voidAction1

        public static <T> Action1<T> voidAction1(TypedMode<Void> mode)

        Parameters:
